title: 109_s811
content: The Act is titled the "Abraham Lincoln Commemorative Coin Act". It includes findings related to the commemoration. Abraham Lincoln, the 16th President, demonstrated courage during the Civil War, rose to the Presidency through honesty and integrity, led efforts to free slaves, had a generous heart, and died from an assassin's bullet in 1865. The year 2009 marks the bicentennial anniversary of his birth. The Abraham Lincoln Bicentennial Commission is planning the celebration of President Lincoln's bicentennial in 2009. A commemorative coin will help fund the celebration and the study of Lincoln's life. SEC. 3 of the Act specifies the coin specifications for $1 silver coins, including weight, diameter, and composition. The coins minted under this Act are legal tender and considered numismatic items. SEC. 4 outlines the design of the coins. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall reflect President Abraham Lincoln's life and legacy, with specific inscriptions and values. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with relevant committees. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single designated mint facility within a one-year period starting January 1, 2009. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins minted under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. Sales of coins minted under this Act will include a $10 surcharge per coin, with all surcharge proceeds promptly paid to the Abraham Lincoln Bicentennial Commission. The Commission will be subject to audit requirements. The Secretary of the Treasury is required to mint coins in commemoration of the bicentennial of the birth of Abraham Lincoln.
